description: From Middle English bondage (“serfdom”), from British Medieval Latin bondagium (“an inferior tenure held by a bond or husbandman”), from Middle English bond (“a tenant farmer, serf”), from Old English bonda (“a householder, husband, head of a family”), of Old Norse origin.

entries.meaning: The state of being enslaved or the practice of slavery.
examples: In Judeo-Christian tradition, the Israelites fled bondage at the hands of the Egyptians, only to wander in the wilderness for the next four decades.

entries.meaning: (by extension) The state of lacking freedom; constraint.
examples: He lived in financial bondage to his cocaine habit; no matter how much he earned, it all seemed to disappear up his nose.

entries.meaning: The practice of physically restraining people for sexual pleasure, such as by tying up or shackling.
examples: Their marriage broke up when she discovered he had been engaging in bondage games with a local dominatrix while he was supposedly working out at the gym.

entries.meaning: (attributive) Applied to clothing with many buckles, zips, etc., associated with punk and goth subcultures.
examples: bondage trousers; bondage jeans; bondage pants
